q: 1. Hardly had the bell rung _____ the students rushed out.
expl: "Hardly … when" is the fixed correlative structure used to show that two actions happened almost at the same moment.

q: 2. No sooner had we reached the gate _____ it began to rain.
expl: "No sooner … than" is required; using any other linker breaks the paired-inversion pattern.

q: 3. Scarcely had I sat down _____ the phone rang.
expl: "Scarcely … when" functions like "hardly … when" after inversion with past perfect.

q: 4. Not until she explained it _____ sense to me.
expl: Fronting a negative adverbial ("Not until …") forces subject–auxiliary inversion: "did it make."

q: 5. Were he to come now, we _____ ready.
expl: In inverted second-conditional sentences ("Were he to …"), the result clause uses "would" + base verb.

q: 6. Should you need help, all you _____ do is ask.
expl: "Should" + subject inversion gives a formal open condition; the main clause keeps the present form "need to."

q: 7. The more carefully you read, _____ errors you will make.
expl: Comparative correlative clauses require the pattern "the more…, the fewer…" with the definite article.

q: 8. It was the village _____ he grew up that he wanted to visit again.
expl: When the antecedent is object of a preposition, formal style keeps the preposition before the relative pronoun: "in which."

q: 9. The reason _____ he left early remains unclear.
expl: After "reason," the most precise formal linker is "for which"; "why" risks redundancy (reason why).

q: 10. He finished the work, after which he _____ a long walk.
expl: "After which" introduces a non-defining relative clause referring to the previous clause; a simple past verb matches the sequence of events.

q: 11. Little did he realise _____ his words would hurt her.
expl: After the inverted adverb "Little," a content clause introduced by "that" reports the fact he failed to realise.

q: 12. Such was her fear _____ she could hardly speak.
expl: "Such … that" result clauses pair the degree word "such" with the linker "that" to show an extreme outcome.

q: 13. Whoever _____ responsible must fix the problem at once.
expl: "Whoever" forms a singular indefinite subject here, so the verb takes singular present form "is."

q: 14. He talked as though he _____ the answer all along.
expl: "As though" for an unreal past situation uses the past perfect: "had known."

q: 15. Had it not been for the map, we _____ lost.
expl: An inverted third-conditional ("Had it not been for …") requires "would have" + past participle in the result clause.

q: 16. Each student may choose whichever topic _____ prefer.
expl: The pronoun refers back to the indefinite singular "each student"; singular "they" keeps the sentence gender-neutral.

q: 17. We will wait here until whoever is in charge _____ .
expl: The verb inside the noun clause headed by "whoever" follows normal present-simple agreement: "arrives."

q: 18. The man _____ dog barked all night has moved away.
expl: "Whose" introduces a relative clause showing possession: "whose dog."

q: 19. Is this the first time _____ you have spoken in public?
expl: "The first/second time" is followed by a defining clause introduced by "that" (often omitted in speech).

q: 20. What surprises me is not _____ he failed but that he failed so badly.
expl: In contrastive constructions, a content clause headed by "that" states the fact being contrasted.
